text:
I‚Äôm 47. We only lose the ability to hear high frequency sounds starting about 50. You can check your current ability via YouTube and someone has gathered them [here](https://decibelhearing.com/hearing-loss-overview/high-frequency-hearing-loss/). I don‚Äôt think there‚Äôs a lot happening up at those frequencies in most music. I could hear the 12K but I couldn‚Äôt hear the 15K.

The frequencies up to 15K that are missing in AAC, often form details of certain instruments and vocals.

There‚Äôs a myth perpetuation about only a small number of people being able to tell the difference. This is usually based on very small samples, like 500 people, or the results of random YouTubers‚Äô tests, or the words of Apple‚Äôs marketing writers. Much of which was said over a decade ago, not considering advancements in drivers today. Neither would form the basis for a scientific fact. 

It would largely depend on the ability of the headphone/earphone to resolve the detail but also your familiarity with the music. It‚Äôs not something you just take random samples and give it a go. It‚Äôs songs you‚Äôve known for years. I remember actually picking up on it with the QCUE‚Äôs for the first time. It‚Äôs a bit like a subtle muffling you get with AAC. Often described as a veil. You don‚Äôt know that you‚Äôre missing something until you have heard the lossless version on the same equipment. I realised something was wrong and that‚Äôs when I discovered Apple Music had glitched and was sending me the AAC version of a song I‚Äôd known for most of my life. It is subtle though. The likes of my casual music fan mother, wouldn‚Äôt care even if she did detect it.

So, for some people, it‚Äôs not a big deal. This is where the difference comes in. For someone that loves a particular artist, they‚Äôre going to want to dig for that extra detail they never knew was there. It can be rewarding and some even find it moving. It is not placebo and anyone saying that is simply inexperienced pretending they‚Äôre not. I‚Äôd actually say the placebo is the other way around. When you haven‚Äôt heard it, you don‚Äôt know that it exists. I was oblivious myself with the original and QCEII‚Äôs. To be fair though, the QCUE‚Äôs are not the ideal tool for picking out the distinction. It would be better to have a multi-driver IEM or over-ear recognised for being highly resolving. It wasn‚Äôt until I got my first IEM‚Äôs that this whole other world opened up to me. A lot of it is ‚Äúear/brain training‚Äù but when you know, you know. There‚Äôs no going back.
